134.-Prescription of public action—Habitually lending money at usurious interest. The prescription of the public action in respect of an offence of habitually lending money at usurious rates of interest is interrupted, if, at the time of the prosecution, a period of three years has not elapsed since the date of the last loan, and if the various operations of usury which constitute the element of habit in such offence were not separated from one another by periods of three years.

135.- Prescription of public action-Prescription of penalty --Sentence in contumacy-Arrest of the person in contumacy. The public action is only prescribed where no proceedings have been instituted within the time-limit fixed by law.

Where a person is sentenced in contumacy for a crime, it is the prescription of the penalty, and not that of the public action, which begins to run from the date of the judgment. Consequently, if such person is arrested before his penalty is barred by prescription, he must be retried in conformity with the terms of Article 224 (.Cr.Pr. even though the ten years fixed for the prescription of the public action in éases of crime have already elapsed. (Cass., Sept. 25, 1920; No. 34.)

113.-Fruits of the pre-empted property--Tender of price.--A pre-emptor is deemed to have become owner of the property pre-empted only from the date of the judgment admitting his claim.

Held, that the pre-emptor, even if he has tendered the price of the property pre-empted, is only entitled to the fruits of such property from the date of the judgment given in his favour, and not from the date of the tender of the price.
(Sum. Trib. Beni Suef, Oct. 28, 1920; No. 147.)

114.-Price-Formal offer of payment (Offre réelle).- -A pre-emptor is not bound to make a formal offer (offre réelle) of the sale price and its accessories; a simple offer of payment is sufficient compliance with the law. (Trib. Alexandria,

115.-Right of redemption--Distinct rights. The right of pre-emption and that of redemption (Article 462 C.C.) are entirely distinct rights both as regards their object and the mode of exercising them.
In fact, whereas pre-emption can only be exercised, in the case of the sale of an immovable property, within the time and subject to the conditions laid down by the Decree of March 23,

1901, the right of redemption may be enforced only where the undivided co-ownership is the result of a contract of partnership, and where one of the partners sells his undivided share in the movable or immovable property of the partnership. (Trib. of Cairo, April 28, 1920 ; No. 10.)

116.--Right of redemption--Co-eristence of both rights. -The scope of application of the right of pre-emption is not the same as that of the right of redemption (Article 462 C.C.); there is no inconsistency in the two rights existing simultaneously. In fact, whereas pre-emption is applicable when a particular immovable property is sold, the right of redemption can only be exercised where an undivided share is sold, either in a partnership property or in an inherited estate. (Trib. Tanta, Dec. 15,

1919 ; No. 9-1.) .-Right of redemption-Relation between the two rights.-In enacting Article 462 C.C. relating to the right of redemption, the Egyptian legislator adopted the principle laid down by Article 841
Fr. C.C., which regulates the retrait successoral, and added thereto the right of redemption in cases of partnership Consequently, the only case where Article 462

C.C. can be applied is that of the sale of an undivided share in the whole of an inherited estate or of partnership property ; but where an undivided share is sold in a specified property, the right of pre-emption can alone be exercised. (App.
May 13, 1920 ; and Trib. of Tanta, March 13,

118.-Sales giving rise to right of pre-emption-Sale made by public auction at the instance of the administrative authorities-Sale made by means of sealed offers.-In view of the ambiguity of the Arabic text of Article 3 of the Decree of March 23, 1901, concerning pre-emption, recourse must be had to the French text. The latter provides for two different cases in which the right of pre-emption cannot be exercised, viz. (a) any sale made by public auction at the instance of the administrative authorities; and (b) a judicial sale by way of licitation or expropriation.

Held, that no right of pre-emption arises in the case of a sale by public auction made by the State of an immovable belonging to it; but that such a right exists where the sale has been made by means of sealed offers. (Trib. App. Assiut, Jan. 29,

119.-Possession--Inversion of title.-A precarious possessor can acquire by prescription as against the owner where the precarious possession is converted into proprietary possession, either in virtue of a title derived from a third party or by the possessor repudiating and resisting the proprietor's claims to ownership.
In the latter case, it is for the courts to decide in every individual case whether the possessor has repudiated the owner's rights sufficiently to operate an inversion of title. (App. May 3, 1920 ;

120.-Suspension-Minors.--The quinquennial acquisitive prescription does not run against minors, the terms of Article 84 C.C. being general and applicable to this prescription as well as to the fifteen years' prescription. (Trib. App. Alexandria, July 13, 19:20; No. 99.)

121.-Wakt-Muhammıdan Law--Action for revindication-Time-limit - Plea of inadmissibility of action.-Since the Civil Code contains no provisions concerning the prescription of Wakf property the matter must be taken as being governed by Muhammadan Law. The rules of this law do not admit of acquisitive prescription of Wakf property, but limit to thirty-three years the period during which an action for its revindication may be brought ; after the expiration of this period, such action is no longer admissible.
(App. March 8, 1920 ; No, 22.)

Peremption of Action.

107.- Effect - Admission made in the course of perempted proceedings.--The peremption of an action annuls only the acts of procedure. An admission made by a party in the course of the proceedings is not included in the peremption, because it is not an act of procedure. Such an admission may, therefore, be invoked in the renewed action.
(Trib. Assiut, April 29, 1920; No. 69.)

108.-Steps in proceelings which interrupt peremption Proceedings before a Meglis Hasby. Steps in the proceedings taken during the period required for the peremption of an action only interrupt the course of such peremption where they are directed against the other party in the case.

Held, that in a case where the court has suspended the hearing of the action until the Meglis Hasby should have appointed a tutor ad litem to represent a party under age, engaged in the case, the application made for this purpose to the Meglis Hasby, before the period of three years has elapsed since the order of suspension, does not interrupt the course of peremption, if no notice has been served, upon the other party, of the application itself or of the decision of the Meglis appointing a tutor. (Sum. Trib. Assint, Sept. 8

The peremption of an action is not covered by a step in the proceedings taken, before the expiration of the time limit of three years, by the registry of the court, of its own motion, and not by one of the parties to the action. 90.—Penal clause-Application-Prejudice.-- Where a penal clause has been stipulated, fixing an indemnity for the case of the infringement of certain conditions of the contract, the party in whose interest the indemnity has been stipulated is not bound, in order to be entitled thereto, to show that he has suffered prejudice as the result of such an infringement by the other party to the contract. In this latter case, the judge should enforce the clause in its entirety.

94.-Default on opposition-Effect.—Article 133, $ 3, C.Cr.Pr., which provides that if the party making opposition does not appear, the opposition shall be avoided, only applies where such party fails to appear at the first hearing of the opposition. Neither can he claim dissolution on the ground that the lessee had sub-let the premises, without his authorization, where it is established that at the time when he brought the first action to obtain payment of the arrears of rent, he was cognizant of the sublease but failed to invoke it as a ground for the dissolution of the lease. It results from the terms of Article 27, § 2, of Law No. 5 of 1907, concerning expropriation for purposes of public utility, that the Nazir of a Wakf, who has the power to alienate the Wakf property, cannot receive parmant of the price of property which has been expropriated for purposes of public utility, unless he has been authorized to do so by the competent authority.

Held, that the Ministry of Public Works is not liable, in such case, for interest on the price which it held back until the authorization in question was produced, neither is the Nazir entitled to claim the revenue of the expropriated property since the date of the expropriation.

8.--Difficulties arising with reference to execution-- Admissiblity of appeal.-Appeal against a judgment given on a difficulty, arising with reference to execution, is inadmissible where the difficulty relates to the merits of the case (as, for instance, the payment of the debt), and the judgment on the merits is itself not liable to appeal, by reason of the amount involved in the suit.

But the case would be otherwise, where the difficulty related to provisional measures. Such measures being considered as of indeterminate amount, appeal would be admissible even if the amount of the principal claim was less than the appealable amount of claims. (Trib. App.
Alexandria, Aug. 3, 1920 ; No. 114.) -Monition of execution—Opposition- Judgment -Time-limit for appeal-Day of service ; v.

12.-Appeal by the accused - Declaration of appeal made by mandatary- Restrictions.-An appeal by an accused against his conviction must be entered by a declaration made by the accused himself (Article 178 C.Cr. Pr.), save in exceptional cases, such as that of a tutor lodging an appeal on behalf of his ward, or of an advocate who holds a power of attorney.

Consequently, a declaration of appeal made on behalf of the accused by a person who does not fulfil such conditions is null and void, ever though such person has been given a specia. mandate for that purpose by the accused.
(Trib. App. Qena, April 6, 1920 ; No. 27.)

13.- Procureur Général - Another official replacing him.--The right, accorded by the last paragraph of Article 177 C.Cr.Pr., to the Procureur Général to lodge appeal within thirty days of the pronouncement of the judgment, in misdemeanour cases, equally belongs to any other member of the Parquet who is fulfilling the duties of Procureur Général per interim.

Consequently, an appeal entered under the terms of the above article is admissible, where it has been made by the Chef du Parquet of the Court of Appeal who was fulfilling the duties of Procureur Général during a vacancy of the post.

Assignment of Claim.

15.-Conditions Debtor's consent-Consent given in advance-Effect. The requirement of the debtor's consent to the assignment of a claim, as between native parties, is not a matter of public policy ; and the debtor may, therefore, renounce the benefit of this provision by making the debt payable to the creditor's order. The assignment of the debt, in such case, is valid once the assignor and assignee are agreed, without need of the debtor's intervention, or of a notice of the assignment being made to him.

Consequently, if the debtor, without ascertaining whether the debt had not been assigned by the creditor to a third party, pays instalments of the debt to the creditor, such payments do not discharge him as against the assignee. (Sum.
Trib. Guirga, May 24, 1920; No. 106.)

16.–Payment by a third party-Difference.-The payment of a debt by a third party, with a right of recourse against the debtor (Article 160 C.C.), is distinguished from the assignment of a claim (Article 319 C.C.) by the intention of such third party, who must have made the payment with the sole object of doing the debtor a service, by liberating him from his obligation to the original creditor.
